bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, January 5, 1954

div1.p: Hench wants the Cubans to present the Finlay Medals to the American recipients.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, January 5, 1954
div1.opener:
January 5, 1954
General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
I developed an acute gastroenteritis in mid-December and have been home
until today. I am feeling better again but quite tired. I anticipate
going to Havana for a quick trip, leaving here January 19, first for
Colorade Springs and Kansas City. It occurred to me that I might be
able, somehow, to stimulate our kind but procrastinating Cuban friends
to deliver to you and to the other yellow fever personalities the decora-
tions which they voted over a year ago. Within a few months after my
own trip to Havana, I wrote to Pedro Nogueira two or three times hinting rather
strongly that since they had been kind enough to vote these honors and
since the potential recipients had heard about it via newspapers and
otherwise, it would be a very kind thing if they could deliver the medals
as they said they would. It was announced in the newspapers that they
would be delivered to the American recipients via Cuban embassies, con-
sulates, etc., but I know Pedro had another idea. He tried, and failed,
to receive authorization to p bring t them himself to the States at the
time of a medical meeting; he can be admired for his desire to present
these personally as certainly nobody else would have understood their
significance and done the honors as well as he. Since he was not
authorized to do it, I imagine the matter is hanging fire.

If you are in the mood to do so, why don't you help me start the ball
rolling by “prodding me.” May I suggest that you write me a letter
somewhat as follows, changing it as you wish.

“In the New York Times a couple of months ago there was a little note
stating that you were to visit Havana and receive a decoration from the
Cuban Government. How I wish that I myself could visit Havana again.

“Speaking of decorations, whatever became of the Finlay Medals granted
to certain yellow fever personalities, the children of Reed, Lazear, etc.,
and to several others of us old-timers? I heard indirectly a year ago
of this honor and heard somewhere that I might receive the decoration
through the local Cuban consulate. I have heard nothing further. As
time is marching on, I wonder if we who were to receive the Finlay Medal
General Albert E. Truby - 2 - January 5, 1954
will hear anything further. Perhaps you could make some discrete in-
quiry from some of our mutual friends in Havana when you go there. I
am sure that General Reed, Blossom Reed and Lazear's children would be
as pleased as I would be to receive the medal as certainly it is a very
real honor and I, for one, appreciate it greatly.”
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
